body.p: LONDON, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Peter Ustinov loves to make people laugh -- but he would dearly like the world to take seriously what he has to say about the future of the planet.
For the Oscar-winning actor, director, playwright, novelist, documentary film-maker and U.N. goodwill ambassador, all too often finds the gales of laughter sweep away the message.
"People are so hungry for him to make them laugh," said John Miller whose new authorised biography of Ustinov, which was published this month is appropriately entitled "The Gift of Laughter."
Revealing a melancholy and reflective streak behind the mask of the clown, Miller said: "He is a serious person who makes his points through humour which is enormously effective."
"There is a streak of melancholy in him that is part of his Russian genes," Miller told Reuters in an interview. "Comic invention is a means of making him snap out of that."

For Ustinov does not view the future of the world through rose-coloured spectacles. "When we did discuss the American presidency and wars in different parts of the world, he seemed very depressed about that," Miller said.
"He is not optimistic about President Bush's leadership of the world and that concerns him very much," he added.

At the age of 81, Ustinov shows no signs of slowing down. Diabetes may have impaired his mobility but Miller said: "His mind is as sharp as ever. I would hope there is quite a lot more to flow from his pen and he is still acting."
Packing the life story of a multi-talented Renaissance man into 250 pages proved a tough assignment for Miller.
Some critics have laid into the book. One called it "a fawning eulogy" and another complained that Miller is "unable to draw our attention to quite how astonishing a phenomenon he is."
Miller defended himself for being such a Ustinov fan but did concede: "It is the most difficult book I have ever written. He was doing about six careers in parallel."
For his c.v. certainly makes impressive reading.
A London revue star as a teenager, Ustinov wrote his first play at 19. He made his first feature film at 25.

He starred in, produced and directed his own plays in London, New York, Berlin, Paris and Rome. He wrote novels to fill in time whilst hanging around on Hollywood film sets. He won two Oscars -- for "Topkapi" and "Spartacus."
He speaks half a dozen languages, has interviewed a string of world leaders, is garlanded with international honours and ranks as one of the world's most gifted raconteurs and mimics.

And Ustinov is the first to admit that laughter has been a life-long drug, confessing: "I was irrevocably betrothed to laughter, the sound of which has always seemed to me to be the most civilised music in the world."
But what would be the ideal epitaph? With a familiar twinkle in his eye, he swiftly decides on the perfect inscription for his tombstone: "Keep off the grass."
